Authors:
Sao Jančič, Hai Nguyen, Jens C Frisvad, Polona Zalar,
Hans-Josef Schroers, Keith Seifert, Nina Gunde-Cimerman
Title:
Consilience in the taxonomic revision of the Wallemia sebi
species complex
Abstract:
Wallemia sebi is a xerophilic food- and air-borne fungus
prevalent in cold, temperate and tropical climates. Cryptic speciation
and phenotypic heterogeneity were previously reported within W. sebi.
Using multi-locus sequence analysis, a companion study, focusing on
Wallemia in the indoor environment, found four phylogenetic species
within the Wallemia sebi species complex (WSSC). In this study, we used
this established phylogenetic species hypothesis to guide phenotypic
assessment of Wallemia sebi from diverse environments and undertook the
formal taxonomic process of describing new species. To reaffirm the
findings of the companion study and because of the wider ecological
range of W. sebi isolates used here, we again performed phylogenetic
analysis using the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions and partial
protein-encoding gene sequences of DNA replication licensing factor
(MCM7), pre-rRNA processing protein (TSR1), RNA polymerase II largest
subunit (RPB1), RNA polymerase II second largest subunit (RPB2) and a
new genetic marker 3´-phosphoadenosine-5´-phosphatase (HAL2). We also
assessed phenotypes by observing culture and micromorphological
characters, xerotolerance, halotolerance, chaotolerance, growth
temperature regimes, extracellular enzyme activities profiling, and
secondary metabolite patterns. Based on the phenotypic observations of
≥100 strains, the Wallemia sebi species complex can be taxonomically
refined to four species, of which three are newly described here as
Wallemia mellicola sp. nov., W. canadensis sp. nov. and W. tropicalis
sp. nov. A key to all of the proposed Wallemia species is provided,
which allowing their identification with physiological,
micromorphological and culture characters.
